cards.html: This is our regular Weekend Reading List, a subscriber-only feature that reviews some major must-reads of the week. If you only read one email from us all week, this one should be it, because it reviews everything we’ve done all week.
Click to share this on Facebook

This newsletter relies on our current subscribers encouraging others to also become subscribers. If you are a monthly subscriber who wants to upgrade to an annual subscription, click here and click “change” in the “Plan” setting. Thanks for your support!

sections: Americans have been terrorized by high health care costs and surprise medical bills. Now, there is new evidence that even though a COVID vaccine is free, the trauma of the experience with for-profit health care may be making many people reluctant to get the vaccine, because they fear being hit with unexpected bills.
Stuff The Daily Poster Reported This Week:
Somehow, There Are Still No Safety Standards
Big Pharma May Finally Lose This One
From Anti-Union Law Firm To Blue-State Governor?
No, Obama Wasn’t Mad About Bailing Out His Wall Street Donors
Big Pharma’s EU Ties Could Stymie Vaccine Waivers
The Covid Vaccine Is Free, But Not Everyone Believes That

Over the course of the pandemic, people have received bills for COVID tests that were supposed to be free, or had claims for COVID treatments denied that were supposed to be covered. As a result, as many as a third of unvaccinated adults fear that they will have to pay for the vaccine, even though they won’t. That could be deterring them from getting vaccinated.
The U.S. Government Hides Some Of Its Darkest Secrets At The Department Of Energy

“Over the last few years, allegations of secret, exotic technologies have reinvigorated claims that the [Department of Defense] may be concealing scientific breakthroughs from the American public. However, if the U.S. government, or some faction within it, hypothetically came across a groundbreaking development in energy production or applied physics, a very strong case could be made that such a revolution would likely be housed deep within the Department of Energy (DOE) rather than DOD.”
The Difficulty of Obtaining an Abortion in Mississippi Is By Design

Are Mississippi’s abortion restrictions, at least in part, intentional policies designed to maintain a low-wage workforce in the state? For one sociologist, “it’s clear that the economic boon for Mississippi businesses provided by the state's restrictive reproductive healthcare laws is inextricably tied to the religious narrative behind them.”
For 5.1 Million Reasons, Cuomo's Book Was Appalling

“But Cuomo wrote his book (supposedly) as the coronavirus pandemic was stealing lives and causing terrible pain. While a more responsible governor would have been totally focused on the pandemic and its devastation, New York’s instead leveraged the crisis for a massive payday.”
Why We Need Paid Leave After Miscarriage in the U.S.

Over one in ten pregnancies end in miscarriage, which can have serious mental and physical health consequences for parents who experience pregnancy loss. Yet, no laws currently exist in the United States to provide workplace protections or paid leave for people who experience miscarriage.

“The For the People Act faces its own anti-democratic hurdle to passage—not one concocted by the Republican Party, but the legislative filibuster, a long-standing feature of the Senate that the Democratic caucus has the power to eliminate or change. Failing to do so would be more than a mere strategic blunder. The Republican Party is waging an assault on multiracial democracy, which even now, two decades into this new century, remains more aspiration than reality. The inequities of the American political system are already deep. If Democrats fail to act, the Republican Party will deepen them beyond hope of repair, securing minority rule for itself and bringing the project of American democracy to an end.”
Jamaal Bowman Is Right — the Left Should Draw a Line in the Sand

“Bowman is exactly right: there is no substantive political case for bargaining down an already compromised infrastructure proposal. If the Biden administration is intent on pursuing such a course, it can and should suffer consequences for scaling down its own plans — and have to contend with lawmakers willing to vote 'nay' before allowing the bogus quest for bipartisanship to water down yet another major piece of legislation.”
The Lab-Leak Theory: Inside the Fight to Uncover COVID-19’s Origins

“A months long Vanity Fair investigation, interviews with more than 40 people, and a review of hundreds of pages of U.S. government documents, including internal memos, meeting minutes, and email correspondence, found that conflicts of interest, stemming in part from large government grants supporting controversial virology research, hampered the U.S. investigation into COVID-19’s origin at every step. In one State Department meeting, officials seeking to demand transparency from the Chinese government say they were explicitly told by colleagues not to explore the Wuhan Institute of Virology’s gain-of-function research, because it would bring unwelcome attention to U.S. government funding of it.”
How Big Pharma Is Undermining Biden

I joined Rising, hosted this week by Ryan Grim and Emily Jashinsky, to discuss the news that Tom Perez, Labor Secretary under President Barack Obama, is joining a union-busting law firm and Big Pharma’s influence on politics around the globe.

If you're feeling overwhelmed by all the news all the time, rest assured — you are not alone. I've been in and around politics for 20+ years, and lately the pace of news has felt more unmanageable than I can ever remember.

Some days I question whether that's just a sign of getting older, but I don't think that's the whole story. The news cycle really has accelerated. So much is happening simultaneously that it's hard to keep up with any of it.
But that's why we do our subscriber-only publications like
The Midday Poster, You Love To See It

— they are the kind of features that aim to boil down some of the most important news of the whole week in small digestible nuggets. Indeed, as I've said before — if you read only one email that we produce each week, make it the
because it reviews all of what we've been reporting over the week, and then gives you an eclectic mix of stories from across the world.

In the coming months, we are aiming to launch some more features that bolster our original reporting, and help you sift through the never ending news cycle. The goal is to help you focus on the signal in all the noise — because the noise so often distracts us all from the really important stories.

, I often joke that it feels like we're trying to improve and expand the plane while simultaneously flying it. We've made great progress in the first year since we launched — but we have a lot more to do, and we are working overtime to build out a full newsroom.
We couldn't do it without the support of our paying subscribers — so thank you for being part of the team, and stay tuned for more soon.
